candidates.title: Flatten connection_client error hierarchy

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: dataplatform
labels.description: Rerun Data Platform integration

candidates.body:
### Related

- Part of RR-2395

### Why
When it comes to exposing errors to client (and specifically thinking at the Python SDK) we want:
- To have meaningful error messages that humans (primarily users and secondarily developers) can understand
- To have actionable types that computers can use to react to errors

Our previous taxonomy of errors in the client was very deeply nested and made it hard to classify the errors
in a way that was machine friendly, i.e., it was hiding very deep the underlying source of the error, and mainly
highlighting the operation where the error happened.

### What

This is an attempt to flatten that taxonomy. All errors generated by the connection client will be of type `ApiError` and 
will have a `ApiErrorKind` of one of few types. The assumption is that those  types are generic across all operations,
and are machine actionable.

`ApiError` is expected to include a human understandable error message string as well as wrapping the underlying `source`
of the error, for further inspection.

### Next
In my ideal mental world, `ExternalError` in `rerun_py` should follow a similar model (or even disappear completely in favor of a more global `ApiError`-equivalent). This will allow to have all the possible error in just a bunch of useful classes instead of this odd mixed taxonomy.

I did not do it in this PR because I would have had too touch way more things I am willing to at this stage.

candidates.body:
### Related

* part of https://linear.app/rerun/project/demo-ready-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines-d0a110693312/
* part of https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2532/pr-tracking-demo-read-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines
* part of https://linear.app/rerun/project/enable-ingestion-workflow-testing-with-oss-server-a73703fc9a94/
* closes https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2322/mock-task-related-endpoints
* sibling https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/1847

### What

This PR moves and adapt a couple of test covering part of registration, partition table and dataset manifest schema and data, and tasks.

It also updates the OSS server as follows:
- The task-related endpoints are mocked.
- The in-memory store use compaction as per env variable (finally not needed for this PR, but I figured I'd leave it anyways)

Notes:
- The dataset manifest is currently disabled if the endpoint is unimplemented, because that's the case in OSS. They will soon be though, and the test will be re-enabled then.
- I made the `size_bytes` field of the manifest implementation-defined (aka it's not covered in snapshots). OSS uses heap size while Cloud uses, I believe, size on disk, and they don't match.

candidates.title: Scaffolding for a shareable, reference test suite for redap

labels.name: 🔨 testing
labels.description: testing and benchmarks

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
### Related

* part of https://linear.app/rerun/project/demo-ready-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines-d0a110693312/
* part of https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2532/pr-tracking-demo-read-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines
* sibling https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/1844

### What

There is no point bringing the OSS server to parity if that parity is neither verified, nor enforced. This PR introduces the scaffolding for a reference Rerun Data Protocol (redap) test suite.

Quoting its README.md:

> This test suite is specifically focused on the redap layer.  In particular it aims to cover what our API's `*.proto` files leave implicit. This includes at least:
> - all the dataframes (schema, content)
> - all the stateful behaviors (e.g. chunk keys, tasks, etc.)
> 
> As such, it is implemented to be as close as possible to the actual API boundary, aka the (incorrectly named) `RerunCloudService` trait.
> 
> ### Goals
> 
> - Cover all aspects of the redap layer, including dataframe schemas and stateful behaviors.
> - Serve as the definitive reference of what redap is.
> - Ensure conformance of all implementations (including, possibly, third-party).
> 
> ### Non-goals
> 
> - Test layers outside the redap boundary, including `re_redap_client::ConnectionClient` or the Python SDK.
> - Test anything about the internals of the redap implementors (OSS server, Rerun Cloud, etc.)

Currently, this test suite contains a single test as proof-of-concept. I've picked one that I thought would pass with both implementations. Of course, it didn't, so this PR also fixes the OSS server so that test passes.

Notes:
- All the code in `util` has been copied straight from the `dataplatform`.
- The crate is marked as `publish = true`. Primarily because CI told me to, but it also kind of make sense given that this crates serves as reference on redap.

candidates.title: Convert remaining deps into workspace deps

labels.name: 🧑‍💻 dev experience
labels.description: developer experience (excluding CI)

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: concerning crates, pip packages etc

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
Done using https://crates.io/crates/cargo-autoinherit

This reverts our previous policy of keeping examples exempt from workspace deps.

The previous policy was based on the idea that it should be easy to copy-and-paste an example, but we never really adhered to that anyway since they all have `rerun = { path = "../../../crates/top/rerun" }` in them.
 
My thinking now is that it's more important to make it easy for us developers to keep our dependency tree nice and updated. In particular, I want to run `cargo upgrade` (from https://crates.io/crates/cargo-edit) and not have dozens of files change

candidates.title: Improve many-entity performance by fixing redundant `AnnotationContext` lookups (also affects scene without annotation contexts)

labels.name: 📉 performance
labels.description: Optimization, memory use, etc

candidates.body: ### Related * small part of https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/8233 ### What "Rea", non-changelog title: "static execution phase for ViewContextSystem & store subscriber for marking up AnnotationContext" For upcoming transform processing I wanted to have a way to execute something _once_ per frame _if_ a context system exists. I tried to make this as low-tech as possible and after a few iteration I came up with `ViewContextSystem::execute_static` which goes a bit out of its way to _not_ introduce a new type of view system. I then figured I could use this to eliminate the extremly wasteful `AnnotationContext` lookups which can amount to a lot of wasted perf. Turns out doing a minimal store subscriber there is the _real_ win, but I made use of `execute_static` regardless for passing on the determined annotations. Using script from https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/11437: ``` pixi run rerun-release --threads=1 pixi run -e py python tests/python/many_entities/main.py ``` Before: After: -> Annotation context no longer shows up as it should (saving us 15ms here without much effort) (resolving non-existant overrides is still horrifying ;-)) Annotations on the "horse example" work still fine: **Review commit by commit recommended (of which there are two ;-))**

candidates.title: Determine per-view overrides in parallel (-> faster many entities + many views on native)

labels.name: 📺 re_viewer
labels.description: affects re_viewer itself

labels.name: 📉 performance
labels.description: Optimization, memory use, etc

candidates.body: ### Related * part of https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/8233 ### Description Override determiniation (even if there are no overrides at all) can get **very** slow for many entities. This PR doesn't address that, but makes it parallel per-view. This alleviates the pain a little bit and was fairly straight forward to do. Came up because I couldn't bear the sight in * https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/11437 Makes it ~neatly~ stacked if multithreading isn't opted out or you're running on the web (this happens to be the slowest part in this synthetic scene which consists entirely of transforms, created via upcoming `pixi run -e py python tests/python/many_entity_transforms/main.py --transforms-only`)

candidates.title: Transform resolution is no longer a store subscriber

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
### Related

* Fixes RR-2489

### What

Mostly a pure refactor. May change perf characteristics a bit, most notably no more transform processing occurs at all until a 3D view is created. Not expecting any major shifts though.

`TransformCacheStoreSubscriber` -> `TransformResolutionCache`

In a nutshell, this removes the tight coupling of transform logic with store subscribers and migrates keeping transforms up to date in the Viewer to a Viewer-Cache.
Chunk events are still used in `TransformResolutionCache` but are a merely a thin aspect of its frontend and can be bypassed for chunk-adding only.

Motivation:
* major step towards coalescing into a multi-faceted `TransformDatabase` object which internally will contain transform resolution cache as well as transform tree
    * `TransformCacheStoreSubscriber` being a subscriber dependency made this unwiedly as we couldn't keep all objects in the same place easily due to the static nature of store subscribers
* tightly control when what is updated and how parallel that happens
* allow transform resolution with partial knowledge - we want to feed in chunks manually and observe the results for the given set of chunks
    * this is important for a query aware future where we can't rely on chugging through fully downloaded stores 


Testing:
Seems to be covered well enough by unit tests on `TransformResolutionCache` as well as integration tests in `re_view_spatial` (both of which prevented mistakes here!)


Reviewing:
Lots of whitespace in existing tests due to nesting decrease (!) as things are no longer happening under a subscriber lock

labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

candidates.body:

* part of https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2532/pr-tracking-demo-read-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines
* closes https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2508/consider-using-chunkstorehandle-instead-of-entitydb-for-oss-server

### What

This PR changes the implementation of the OSS server to use `ChunkStoreHandle` instead of `EntityDb` to store the data, and disables all compaction/subscribers on the store.

candidates.title: Update wgpu to 27

labels.name: 🔺 re_renderer
labels.description: rendering, graphics, GPU

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: concerning crates, pip packages etc

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
Allows us to remove some very dreaded `unsafe` code \o/

Went on a rabbit-hole trip to use the fancy new `map_buffer_on_submit` methods. But it's actually really hard to do so because by design, our read/write belts can use a single chunk (==buffer) on multiple command encoders. Therefore, it's really hard to know which command encoder is the one that you call `map_buffer_on_submit` on.
I noted down my learnings in the code comments, hopefully that prevents future generations to get confused by this.


Testing
* [x] Windows native
* [ ] Linux native
* [x] Mac native
* [x] WebGL
* [x] WebGPU

candidates.title: Store (and display) recordings in insertion order

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: ui
labels.description: concerns graphical user interface

candidates.body:
### Related

* closes https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2340/order-partitions-by-the-opening-order

### What

This PR changes `StoreBundle` to use an `indexmap` instead of a `HashMap`, such that all iterator are sorted by insertion order. The main benefit is that recordings (and, in particular, partitions) are now ordered by opening order in the recording panel.

candidates.title: Move transform processing modules into new, viewer-independent `re_tf` crate

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

candidates.body:
### Related

* Fixes RR-2481

### What

Going forward we want tranform queries to exist outside of the viewer, so questions like "what is the spatial relationship between a and b" can be answered programmatically. This PR takes the first step by moving all the pieces out and making them independent of the Viewer's environment.

`TransformTree` needed a little bit of decoupling, but otherwise this was quite straight forward!
We still have strong dependencies to re_query and EntityDb in general which are a bit harder to avoid since we're relying heavily on the there encoded query logic. But it's a much better starting point and gives us good initial constraints going forward.

@ reviewer: `crates/store/re_tf/src/transform_tree.rs` is a rename from `crates/viewer/re_view_spatial/src/contexts/transform_tree_context.rs`, I merely adjusted some function signature to unpack some viewer exclusive constructs (see the remaining/new `transform_tree_context` to learn what is necessary to do so)

candidates.title: Introduce `Lens` as a concept for semantic mapping of arbitrary data

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

candidates.body:
### Related

* [x] Requires #11383.
* [x] Requires #11456.
* [x] Requires #11454.

### What

This PR introduces the concept of _Lenses_ as a way to express re-interpretation and manipulation of component columns. This can, for example, be useful to attach Rerun semantics to arbitrary Arrow components that are created when loading MCAP files.

For now, the only way to access the feature is via the `LensesSink`, which transforms component columns and then forwards aggregated chunks to the backing sink.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> Lenses are still a very experimental feature and we expect the API to change a lot in upcoming releases.

chosen_pr.body:
### Related

- Part of RR-2395

### Why
When it comes to exposing errors to client (and specifically thinking at the Python SDK) we want:
- To have meaningful error messages that humans (primarily users and secondarily developers) can understand
- To have actionable types that computers can use to react to errors

Our previous taxonomy of errors in the client was very deeply nested and made it hard to classify the errors
in a way that was machine friendly, i.e., it was hiding very deep the underlying source of the error, and mainly
highlighting the operation where the error happened.

### What

This is an attempt to flatten that taxonomy. All errors generated by the connection client will be of type `ApiError` and 
will have a `ApiErrorKind` of one of few types. The assumption is that those  types are generic across all operations,
and are machine actionable.

`ApiError` is expected to include a human understandable error message string as well as wrapping the underlying `source`
of the error, for further inspection.

### Next
In my ideal mental world, `ExternalError` in `rerun_py` should follow a similar model (or even disappear completely in favor of a more global `ApiError`-equivalent). This will allow to have all the possible error in just a bunch of useful classes instead of this odd mixed taxonomy.

I did not do it in this PR because I would have had too touch way more things I am willing to at this stage.
